feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Montgomery

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:49PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: A couple waves of energy will bring the potential for snow squalls Saturday through Sunday night. Squalls are notoriously quick in nature, but can bring brief heavy bursts of snow and wind gusts up to 35 mph which can reduce visibility below 1 mile at times. Snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches is possible, with the heaviest expected in the Western Seward Peninsula and most of it coming Saturday night through Sunday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; St Lawrence Island

cap:parameter.value: Snow Squalls Possible Saturday and Sunday

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:48PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: Light snow fell overnight and during the day Friday across many parts of the Interior. Most accumulations were on the order of 1 to 3 inches. While most roadways have remained wet as opposed to icy today, that could change overnight. Additional light snow is expected later tonight and throughout the day Saturday. In addition most areas will see temperatures drop into the upper 20's to near 30 degrees overnight which could result in some icy conditions for local roadways overnight tonight and early Saturday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: White Mountains and High Terrain South of the Yukon River; Fortymile Country; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Central Interior; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 2:15PM PDT until October 18 at 12:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement. A moderate risk of sneaker waves. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 20-25 feet expected.
* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.
* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Saturday morning. For the High Surf Advisory, from 11 AM Sunday to 11 AM PDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping anyone caught underneath. Large breaking waves will create hazardous conditions along and within the surf zone, and could inundate beaches and low lying shorelines. Beach erosion is possible, and exposed infrastructure may be damaged.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The risk of sneaker waves will peak this evening, but seas will continue to build through Saturday morning and linger through the day Saturday. After brief improvement Saturday night, hazardous conditions due to high surf are expected late Sunday into early Monday with the highest waves peaking out Sunday night.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH SATURDAY MORNING... ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM SUNDAY TO 11 AM PDT MONDAY

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 1:59PM PDT until October 19 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.
* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South Washington Coast.
* WHEN...For the first Beach Hazards Statement, from this afternoon through Saturday evening. For the second Beach Hazards Statement, from Sunday afternoon through Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or drowning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of children and pets.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH SUNDAY EVENING

entry.title: Frost Advisory issued October 17 at 2:11PM MDT until October 18 at 9:00AM MDT by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Temperatures 33 to 37 will result in frost formation.
* WHERE...The lower Snake Plain, including the Treasure Valley and western Magic Valley.
* WHEN...Until 9 AM MDT /8 AM PDT/ Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 17 at 4:02PM EDT until October 18 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding.
* WHERE...Florida Keys.
* WHEN...Through early Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets and lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some seawalls and docks will be overtopped. Boaters can expect less clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost certain to contain a mix of saltwater. In the Upper Keys, there will be little relief in minor salt water flooding, even at around the times of high tide.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
entry.cap:areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 17 at 12:56PM PDT until October 19 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...High elevation snow expected. Total snow accumulations up to 4 to 8 inches.
* WHERE...Cascades of Whatcom and Skagit Counties including Rainy Pass. Heaviest accumulation above 4500 feet.
* WHEN...From 11 PM Saturday to 11 PM PDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow accumulations will occur above 4000 feet. People planning on visiting the backcountry should plan accordingly for winter weather conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cascades of Whatcom and Skagit Counties

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 11 PM SATURDAY TO 11 PM PDT SUNDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 17 at 12:48PM PDT until October 19 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Accumulations of 4 to 8 inches possible.
* WHERE...Areas of Western Okanogan County above 4000 feet including Washington Pass.
* WHEN...From 11 PM Saturday to 11 PM PDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Travel could be very difficult.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Okanogan County

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 11 PM SATURDAY TO 11 PM PDT SUNDAY

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued October 17 at 1:39PM MDT until October 19 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Denver has issued a Fire Weather Watch for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect Sunday afternoon.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 216, 239, 241, 246 and 247.
* TIMING...Sunday afternoon.
* WINDS...Southwest 10 to 15 mph with gusts 25 to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...10 to 15%.
* IMPACTS...Conditions will be favorable for rapid fire spread. Avoid outdoor burning and any activity that may produce a spark and start a wildfire.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jefferson and West Douglas Counties Above 6000 Feet/Gilpin/Clear Creek/Northeast Park Counties Below 9000 Feet; Boulder And Jefferson Counties Below 6000 Feet/West Broomfield County; Elbert/Central and East Douglas Counties Above 6000 Feet; North and Northeast Elbert County Below 6000 Feet/North Lincoln County; Southeast Elbert County Below 6000 Feet/South Lincoln County

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT SUNDAY AFTERNOON FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR JEFFERSON, LINCOLN, AND EASTERN BOULDER COUNTIES, AS WELL AS THE PALMER DIVIDE

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 12:36PM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.
* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern Monterey Bay, Southern Monterey Bay, and Big Sur Coast.
* WHEN...From 8 PM PDT this evening through Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should always swim near a lifeguard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 8 PM PDT THIS EVENING THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:04PM CDT by NWS Corpus Christi TX
entry.summary: The combination of light winds and abundant tropical moisture will make the atmosphere favorable for the development of weak tropical funnels today. Most of these funnel clouds will be short lived and usually do not touch the ground. However, you should be prepared to seek shelter in the event a funnel does reach the ground.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Aransas; Aransas Islands; Coastal Calhoun; Calhoun Islands

* WHEN...Until 6 AM MDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Mainly to transportation. Strong cross winds will be hazardous to light weight or high profile vehicles, including campers and tractor trailers.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A brief lull in winds is expected between noon and 6pm on Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Laramie Range and Southwest Platte County; East Platte County; South Laramie Range; South Laramie Range Foothills

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 11:58AM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves, and strong longshore currents in the surf zone.
* WHERE...The beaches north of Cape Hatteras.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 11:30 AM Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Outer Banks; Hatteras Island

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM EDT THIS EVENING NORTH OF CAPE HATTERAS

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 17 at 10:13AM EDT until October 18 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and Marion Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow morning.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flood waters will begin to affect residential yards in the Fork Retch community upstream of Galivants Ferry near the town of Nichols. Swampland flooding becomes noticeable and natural boat landings will be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 AM EDT Friday the stage was 9.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this afternoon and continue falling to 6.1 feet Wednesday morning. - Flood stage is 9.0 feet. - weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Horry, SC; Marion, SC

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 17 at 8:58AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.
.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However, tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest to the river on McPherson Lane.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 AM EDT Friday the stage was 3.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 AM EDT Friday was 3.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 3.2 feet today into early Saturday, falling slightly to 3.1 feet this weekend. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 4:52AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: A couple waves of energy will bring the potential for snow squalls Saturday through Sunday night. Squalls are notoriously quick in nature, but can bring brief heavy bursts of snow and wind gusts up to 35 mph which can reduce visibility below 1 mile at times. Snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches is possible, with the heaviest expected in the Western Seward Peninsula and most of it coming Saturday night through Sunday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; St Lawrence Island

cap:parameter.value: Snow Squalls Possible Saturday and Sunday

entry.title: Lake Wind Advisory issued October 17 at 12:38AM MDT until October 17 at 7:00PM MDT by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Southwest to west winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 30 mph expected. A few showers may bring erratic wind gusts over 35 mph.
* WHERE...Flathead Lake and other area lakes around the Flathead and Mission valleys.
* WHEN...From 11 AM this morning to 7 PM MDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Strong winds and rough waves on area lakes will create hazardous conditions for small craft.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Choppy waves of 1 to 3 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Flathead/Mission Valleys

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 11:03PM PDT until October 19 at 12:00AM PDT by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast, Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.
* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening. .
* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Del Norte; Northern Humboldt Coast; Southwestern Humboldt; Mendocino Coast

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 11:02AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A pair of light disturbances will impact the Interior, bringing light snowfall throughout the evening tonight through the weekend. Accumulations of 1-3 inches of snow are expected through this weekend with higher amounts in higher elevations and areas near Healy.
Due to the colder temperatures setting in, this could bring our first permanent snowpack for some areas. Snowfall is expected to accumulate on roadways, making travel conditions difficult at times.
entry.cap:areaDesc: White Mountains and High Terrain South of the Yukon River; Fortymile Country; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Central Interior; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

cap:parameter.value: Light Snowfall Tonight Through This Weekend

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 15 at 10:16AM CDT until October 19 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Aberdeen SD
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Dakota...
James River near Stratford affecting Brown and Spink Counties.
.For sites with a river forecast, the forecast includes precipitation through the next 48 hours. Any future precipitation could affect the forecasts.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...James River near Stratford.
* WHEN...Until Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Significant amounts of agricultural lands begin flooding.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:45 AM CDT Wednesday the stage was 14.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:45 AM CDT Wednesday was 14.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to continue a slow fall below flood stage early Sunday afternoon. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Brown, SD; Spink, SD
